facts: Large raptor with white head and tail; dark brown body.
Genus: Haliaeetus, Species: leucocephalus
Best Seen: Yellowstone Lake, Hayden Valley, near major rivers.
Diet: Primarily fish, but also carrion and small mammals.
Nests in large trees near water.
Year-round resident in Yellowstone.
Wingspan up to 7.5 feet.
Symbol of the United States.
Often seen soaring or perched near water.
Recovering from previous endangered status due to DDT.
Specialized fish-eating raptor with M-shaped flight pattern.
Genus: Pandion, Species: haliaetus
Best Seen: Yellowstone River, Yellowstone Lake, Firehole River.
Builds large stick nests on dead trees or platforms.
Dives feet-first into water to catch fish.
Migratory: returns in spring and leaves by fall.
White head with dark eye stripe.
Nests often reused year after year.
Monogamous pair bonds during breeding season.
Screeching call often heard near water.
Largest native waterfowl species in North America.
Genus: Cygnus, Species: buccinator
Best Seen: Yellowstone Lake, Madison River, Lamar Valley.
All-white body with black bill and feet.
Primarily herbivorous, feeding on aquatic vegetation.
Endangered in early 1900s, now rebounding.
Pairs mate for life.
Very territorial during breeding.
Haunting, deep honking call.
Nests in marshes and shallow lakes.
Tall, gray bird with red crown and long legs.
Genus: Antigone, Species: canadensis
Best Seen: Lamar Valley, Hayden Valley, meadows near wetlands.
Elaborate courtship dances.
Eats grains, insects, small animals, and roots.
Monogamous pairs nest on ground in marshes.
Distinct rolling bugle call.
Migratory: returns in spring.
Fossil record dates back over 2 million years.
Juveniles are cinnamon-colored.
Small, plump gray songbird that 'dips' up and down.
Genus: Cinclus, Species: mexicanus
Best Seen: Fast-moving streams like Gibbon River and Firehole River.
Only aquatic songbird in North America.
Walks underwater to feed on insects and larvae.
Often bobs on rocks midstream.
Nests on rock ledges and under bridges.
Sings sweet, warbling song year-round.
Resident year-round, even in winter.
Indicator of healthy stream ecosystems.
Largest owl by length in North America.
Genus: Strix, Species: nebulosa
Best Seen: Forest edges near Hayden Valley and Canyon.
Facial disc helps amplify sound to detect prey.
Silent flight and patient hunting.
Eats mainly voles and small mammals.
Nests in broken-topped trees or old nests.
Difficult to spot but worth the search.
Breeds in Yellowstone's subalpine forests.
Rare but regularly observed in early morning or dusk.
Bright blue male, pale gray-blue female.
Genus: Sialia, Species: currucoides
Best Seen: Lamar Valley, Tower Junction, Blacktail Plateau.
Nests in cavities or nest boxes.
Eats insects and berries.
State bird of Idaho and Nevada.
Hover-gleaning insect catch technique.
Favors open meadows and sagebrush flats.
Short migratory movements depending on winter severity.
Symbol of happiness in western folklore.
Gray bird with black wings and long beak.
Genus: Nucifraga, Species: columbiana
Best Seen: Subalpine forests near Mount Washburn and Dunraven Pass.
Caches thousands of pine seeds for winter.
Major seed disperser for whitebark pine.
Very intelligent corvid family member.
Harsh 'kraaa' call echoes through forests.
Pairs defend territories year-round.
Nests early in the season (as early as February).
Dependent on conifer cone crops.
Medium-sized hawk with owl-like face and long tail.
Genus: Circus, Species: hudsonius
Best Seen: Hayden Valley, Lamar Valley meadows.
Low, gliding flight style while hunting.
Eats small mammals, birds, and insects.
Females are larger and brown; males are gray.
Often perches on low snags or fence posts.
Nests on the ground in dense vegetation.
Distinct white rump patch visible in flight.
Uses hearing and vision to detect prey.
Common large hawk with reddish tail.
Genus: Buteo, Species: jamaicensis
Best Seen: Road corridors, open fields, Lamar Valley.
Soars in circles with broad wings.
Emits the classic 'screech' used in movies.
Feeds on rodents, rabbits, reptiles.
Nests in trees, cliffs, or human structures.
Highly adaptable and widespread.
Juveniles lack red tail initially.
Often seen perched along roadsides.
Fastest bird on Earth, dives at 240 mph.
Genus: Falco, Species: peregrinus
Best Seen: Cliffs near Yellowstone River, Tower Fall.
Feeds primarily on birds mid-flight.
Recovered from DDT-related decline.
Slate-gray back, barred white chest.
Dark helmet-like head markings.
Highly territorial during nesting.
Nests on cliffs and rock ledges.
Known for sharp 'kek-kek-kek' calls.
Bright yellow body with red-orange head (male).
Genus: Piranga, Species: ludoviciana
Best Seen: Forest edges near Mammoth and Tower.
Females are olive-yellow with dark wings.
Eats insects and fruit.
Migrates from Central America in spring.
Soft warbling song from canopy.
Rarely seen but easily heard.
Prefers mixed conifer and aspen forest.
Eye-catching flash of color among trees.
Small, colorful falcon with fast flight.
Genus: Falco, Species: sparverius
Best Seen: Open areas near roadways and meadows.
Males have blue-gray wings and orange back.
Feeds on insects, small mammals, and birds.
Nests in cavities and nest boxes.
Hover-hunting style distinctive in Yellowstone.
Rapid 'klee-klee-klee' call when alarmed.
Widespread across North America.
Prefers low perches to scan for prey.
Diving duck with round head and striking yellow eye.
Genus: Bucephala, Species: islandica
Best Seen: Yellowstone Lake and Gibbon River.
Males have black-and-white plumage with purple sheen.
Females are brown with orange bill tips.
Feeds on aquatic insects and crustaceans.
Nests in tree cavities near water.
Dives underwater to forage.
Distinctive whistling wing sound in flight.
Winter range includes thermal waters of Yellowstone.
Large, intelligent black bird with shaggy throat.
Genus: Corvus, Species: corax
Best Seen: Throughout the park in all habitats.
Known for problem-solving and tool use.
Loud, varied vocalizations and aerial acrobatics.
Omnivorous scavenger and hunter.
Pairs mate for life and nest in cliffs and trees.
Widespread in North America and Yellowstone.
Tails wedge-shaped in flight.
Cultural symbol in many Native traditions.
Fluffy gray bird known as the 'camp robber.'
Genus: Perisoreus, Species: canadensis
Best Seen: Subalpine forests near Canyon and Mount Washburn.
Caches food for winter in bark and moss.
Inquisitive and often fearless of humans.
Feeds on insects, berries, and carrion.
Soft whistles and chattering calls.
Nests in late winter while snow is still deep.
Highly intelligent corvid family member.
Believed to bring good luck in some traditions.
Distinctive black and white striped crown.
Genus: Zonotrichia, Species: leucophrys
Best Seen: Meadows and sagebrush flats.
Sweet, whistled song common at dawn.
Eats seeds and insects.
Ground-nester under shrubs or grass.
Migratory: summers in Yellowstone.
Young lack the crown stripes.
Often found in small flocks.
Known for regional song dialects.
Bright yellow with reddish streaks on breast (male).
Genus: Setophaga, Species: petechia
Best Seen: Riparian areas along Firehole and Gibbon Rivers.
Favors willows and shrubs near water.
Feeds on insects and caterpillars.
Rapid, musical song of 'sweet-sweet-sweet.'
Nests low in shrubs and small trees.
One of the most widespread warblers in North America.
Arrives in late spring, departs early fall.
Females are slightly duller than males.
Massive white bird with orange bill and black wingtips.
Genus: Pelecanus, Species: erythrorhynchos
Best Seen: Yellowstone Lake, Pelican Creek, and Yellowstone River.
Soars in flocks or glides low over water.
Feeds by dipping beak into water—not plunge-diving.
Breeds colonially on isolated islands.
Migratory: returns in late spring.
One of the largest birds in the park.
Nest colonies are protected and restricted.
Wing span can exceed 9 feet.
Small yellow warbler with black cap (male).
Genus: Cardellina, Species: pusilla
Best Seen: Willows near streams and wet meadows.
Often flits low in dense vegetation.
Feeds on insects and small invertebrates.
Sings sharp chattering warble.
Migrates from Central America.
Nests low in shrubs or grasses.
Quick and elusive in movement.
Female lacks black cap entirely.
